cells.source:
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import pandas as pd

# URL of the page containing GameStop's quarterly revenue data
url = "https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/GME/gamestop/revenue"

# Send an HTTP request to get the page content
response = requests.get(url)

# Parse the page content with BeautifulSoup
soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, "html.parser")

# Find the table containing the revenue data
table = soup.find('table', {'class': 'historical_data_table'})

# Extract the rows from the table
rows = table.find_all('tr')

# Initialize lists to store the data
dates = []
revenues = []

# Loop through each row in the table (skip the header row)
for row in rows[1:]:
    columns = row.find_all('td')
    if len(columns) > 1:
        date = columns[0].text.strip()
        revenue = columns[1].text.strip().replace('B', ' Billion').replace('$', '').replace(',', '')
        
        # Append the data to the lists
        dates.append(date)
        revenues.append(revenue)

# Create a DataFrame
gme_revenue_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Date': dates,
    'Revenue': revenues
})

# Convert the 'Revenue' column to numeric values (optional, for easier analysis)
gme_revenue_df['Revenue'] = pd.to_numeric(gme_revenue_df['Revenue'], errors='coerce')

# Display the last five rows
print(gme_revenue_df.tail())

cells.source:
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import pandas as pd

# Define the URL for GameStop revenue data
url = "https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/GME/gamestop/revenue"

# Send a GET request to the URL
response = requests.get(url)

# Parse the page content
soup = BeautifulSoup(response.content, 'html.parser')

# Find the table containing the revenue data
table = soup.find('table', {'class': 'historical_data_table'})

# Verify if the table exists
if not table:
    print("Table not found. Please check the webpage structure or use an alternative method.")
else:
    # Extract rows from the table
    rows = table.find_all('tr')

    # Parse the table rows into a list of lists
    data = []
    for row in rows[1:]:  # Skip the header row
        cols = row.find_all('td')
        cols = [col.text.strip() for col in cols]
        if len(cols) == 2:  # Ensure two columns (Date and Revenue)
            data.append(cols)

    # Convert the data into a DataFrame
    gme_revenue = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['Date', 'Revenue'])

    # Clean up Revenue column by removing commas and dollar signs
    gme_revenue['Revenue'] = gme_revenue['Revenue'].str.replace(',', '').str.replace('$', '')
    gme_revenue['Revenue'] = pd.to_numeric(gme_revenue['Revenue'], errors='coerce')

    # Display the last five rows of the dataframe
    print(gme_revenue.tail())

cells.source:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Define the function to create and display the graph
def make_graph(data, title, x_label, y_label):
    plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
    plt.plot(data[x_label], data[y_label], label=y_label, color='blue')
    plt.title(title)
    plt.xlabel(x_label)
    plt.ylabel(y_label)
    plt.grid()
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Load Tesla stock data (assuming it's already extracted)
import yfinance as yf
tesla_data = yf.Ticker("TSLA").history(period="5y")
tesla_data.reset_index(inplace=True)

# Use the function to plot the Tesla stock graph

make_graph(tesla_data, "Tesla Stock Price Over Time", "Date", "Close")

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import yfinance as yf

# Define the make_graph function
def make_graph(data, title, x_label, y_label):
    plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
    plt.plot(data[x_label], data[y_label], label=y_label, color='green')
    plt.title(title)
    plt.xlabel(x_label)
    plt.ylabel(y_label)
    plt.grid()
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()

# Fetch GameStop stock data using yfinance
gme_data = yf.Ticker("GME").history(period="5y")
gme_data.reset_index(inplace=True)

# Use the make_graph function to plot the GameStop stock graph
make_graph(gme_data, "GameStop Stock Price Over Time", "Date", "Close")
